verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,
verses.comment: The instructions come directly from the LORD to the leaders of Israel, emphasizing divine authority behind the laws of purity.

verses.text: "When a person has on his skin a swelling, a scab, or a bright spot, and it becomes a disease like leprosy on the skin, he shall be brought to Aaron the priest, or to one of his sons the priests."
verses.comment: Notice the priestly role in discerning purity, foreshadowing spiritual discernment and mediation in New Testament ministry. The term "leprosy" here covers a variety of skin conditions, not strictly Hansen's disease.

verses.text: The priest shall examine the diseased area on the skin. If the hair in the affected spot has turned white, and the area looks deeper than the skin, it is a case of leprosy. When the priest examines him, he shall declare him unclean.
verses.comment: The priest judges not only physical symptoms, but spiritual purity. This foreshadows Christ's healing and pronouncement of cleanness (Luke 5:13).

verses.text: But if the spot is white on his skin and does not look deeper than the skin, and the hair has not turned white, the priest shall isolate the person for seven days.
verses.comment: The priest acts with caution, requiring isolation for observation. In spiritual interpretation, this highlights the careful discernment of sin in the community.

verses.text: The priest shall examine him on the seventh day. If the disease is unchanged and has not spread in the skin, then the priest shall isolate him for another seven days.
verses.comment: The process extends with patience and repeated examination, emphasizing spiritual vigilance and pastoral care.

verses.text: After another seven days, the priest shall examine him again. If the spot has faded and has not spread, the priest shall pronounce him clean—it is only a scab. The person shall wash his clothes and be clean.
verses.comment: Ritual washing anticipates baptismal imagery, cleansing from impurity—see Revelation 7:14 for typology.

verses.text: But if the scab spreads in the skin after being shown to the priest and pronounced clean, he must be examined again.
verses.comment: Even after initial cleansing, continued vigilance is required—this calls to mind continual spiritual examination.

verses.text: If the priest sees that the scab has indeed spread in the skin, he shall pronounce him unclean—this is leprosy.
verses.comment: Uncleanness is formally declared by the priest, with authority to bind and loose—see Matthew 16:19 for spiritual application.

verses.text: When someone has a disease like leprosy, he must be brought to the priest.
verses.comment: Bringing the afflicted to the priest prefigures Christ sending the healed lepers to the priest (Matt. 8:4), giving insight into the enduring sacramental ministry.

verses.text: The priest must examine the person. If there is a white swelling on the skin and the hair has turned white, and there is raw flesh in the swelling,
verses.comment: Specific signs identify uncleanness, paralleling discernment between mortal and venial failings.

verses.text: it is a chronic leprosy. The priest shall declare him unclean and not isolate him, for he is already unclean.
verses.comment: No isolation needed if uncleanness is manifest, symbolizing serious sin requiring immediate action rather than gradual discernment.

verses.text: If the disease spreads over the skin, covering all of the body from head to foot, wherever the priest looks,
verses.comment: Universal uncleanness can be compared with total depravity of the body in prophetic imagery (Isaiah 1:6).

verses.text: then the priest shall examine the person. If the leprosy has covered his whole body but has turned uniformly white, he shall declare him clean.
verses.comment: A paradox: complete whiteness, not raw, is declared clean. This signifies cleansing by grace from the fullness of sin. See spiritual restoration typology.

verses.text: But when raw flesh appears in him, he shall be declared unclean.
verses.comment: Raw flesh indicates active disease—symbolizing unrepented, manifest sin.

verses.text: The priest shall examine the raw flesh and declare him unclean, for raw flesh is unclean—it is leprosy.
verses.comment: Hebrew emphasizes that open, living flesh is 'unclean'—pointing to biblical teaching on purity and interior renewal.

verses.text: But if the raw flesh recovers and turns white again, he shall come to the priest.
verses.comment: Healing and restoration is possible once uncleanness is gone—a subtle typology for confession and restoration (see James 5:15–16).

verses.text: The priest shall examine him. If the affected area is turned white, the priest shall pronounce the person clean.
verses.comment: The priest's authority to pronounce cleanness is echoed in Christ's instructions (see Matthew 8:4).

verses.text: "If the body develops a boil and it heals,
verses.comment: Here begins instruction about skin conditions following boils, showing meticulous concern for bodily and spiritual health.

verses.text: and in its place there comes a white swelling or a reddish-white spot, the person shall be shown to the priest.
verses.comment: Priestly examination extends widely, paralleling vigilance in spiritual direction.

verses.text: The priest shall examine it. If it appears deeper than the skin and the hair has turned white, the priest shall declare him unclean—this is leprosy from the boil.
verses.comment: Physical evidence determines uncleanness; this highlights the visible signs of spiritual sickness in Scripture.

verses.text: But if the priest examines it and there is no white hair, and it is not deeper than the skin but has faded, the priest shall isolate him for seven days.
verses.comment: Isolation for discernment continues—a sign of patient pastoral guidance.

verses.text: If it spreads further in the skin, the priest shall pronounce him unclean—it is leprosy.
verses.comment: Leprosy's progression corresponds to unchecked sin corrupting the soul.

verses.text: But if the spot has not spread and has faded, it is just the scar from the boil, and the priest shall declare him clean.
verses.comment: Faded scars signal healing, pointing toward restoration after discipline.

verses.text: "Or when the body receives a burn from fire, and the raw area becomes a reddish-white or white spot,
verses.comment: Burn injuries are also covered by priestly ruling, stressing the comprehensive care of the faith community.

verses.text: the priest shall examine it. If the hair in the spot has turned white, and it appears deeper than the skin, it is leprosy from the burn and the priest shall declare him unclean.
verses.comment: The nature of the affliction is judged by its signs, echoing the methodical discernment of the spiritual shepherd.

verses.text: But if the priest examines it and there is no white hair, and it is not deeper than the skin but has faded, the priest shall isolate him for seven days.
verses.comment: Prudence dictates isolation and observation—mirroring careful spiritual testing.

verses.text: On the seventh day the priest shall examine him. If the spot has spread in the skin, the priest shall declare him unclean—it is leprosy.
verses.comment: Progression signals uncleanness, as unchecked spiritual maladies require intervention.

verses.text: If the spot remains unchanged and has not spread and has faded, it is just the scar from the burn, and the priest shall declare him clean.
verses.comment: No uncleanness from healing, reflecting the grace given after suffering.

verses.text: "If a man or woman has a disease on the head or beard,
verses.comment: Instruction now extends to diseases affecting hair—symbolically connecting to consecration and the human dignity given by God.

verses.text: the priest shall examine the disease. If it appears deeper than the skin and the hair in it is yellow and thin, the priest shall declare them unclean—it is an itch, a disease of the head or beard.
verses.comment: Yellow, thin hair marks uncleanness; this attention to detail illustrates spiritual discernment.

verses.text: If, when the priest examines the disease, it does not seem deeper than the skin and there is no black hair in it, the priest shall isolate the affected person for seven days.
verses.comment: Black hair signals health, so absence leads to caution, indicative of prudent pastoral examination.

verses.text: On the seventh day the priest shall examine the disease. If it does not spread and has no yellow hair, and it is not deeper than the skin,
verses.comment: Lack of worsening suggests cleanness, drawing a parallel to overcoming spiritual trials.

verses.text: the person must shave but not shave the afflicted area. Then the priest shall isolate him for another seven days.
verses.comment: Shaving the surrounding area aids examination, a detail echoing careful and systematic spiritual discernment.

verses.text: On the seventh day the priest shall examine the disease again. If it has not spread and has no deeper appearance and there is no yellow hair, the priest shall declare him clean. He shall wash his clothes and be clean.
verses.comment: Washed garments are a ritual of purification, connecting to spiritual renewal and justification.

verses.text: But if the disease spreads after being declared clean,
verses.comment: Change after cleansing means reevaluation—connects with vigilance in penance and mercy.

verses.text: the priest shall examine him. If the disease has spread, the priest does not need to seek further signs, for the person is unclean.
verses.comment: Manifest uncleanness requires no further signs—the teaching here suggests certainty in correcting manifest sin.

verses.text: But if the affected area remains unchanged and black hair has grown in it, the disease has healed. The person is clean, and the priest shall declare him clean.
verses.comment: Black hair marks health and the priest's declaration gives certainty and peace, echoing spiritual absolution.

verses.text: "When a man or a woman has spots of white on the skin,
verses.comment: Here begins a new section on minor skin diseases, showing that not all imperfections are impurities.

verses.text: the priest shall examine them. If the white spots are dull, it is only a harmless rash. The person is clean.
verses.comment: Not every affliction signals impurity—echoes the wisdom of distinguishing serious sin from scrupulosity.

verses.text: "If a man loses his hair and becomes bald, he is clean.
verses.comment: Baldness itself is not a mark of impurity, showing mercy in the law's application.

verses.text: If the hair falls off from the front of his head, he is bald on the forehead, but he is clean.
verses.comment: Again, hair loss is not a moral or ritual impurity—displaying sensitivity to human condition.

verses.text: But if there is a reddish-white disease on the bald head or forehead,
verses.comment: A new affliction arises, requiring priestly discernment, echoing need for pastoral care throughout life.

verses.text: the priest shall examine him. If the swelling of the disease is reddish-white on the bald head or forehead, like the leprosy on the skin,
verses.comment: External similarity to leprosy requires priestly ruling—mirroring spiritual discernment.

verses.text: he is a leprous man, he is unclean. The priest shall stoutly declare him unclean. The disease is on his head.
verses.comment: Clear, careful judgment marks genuine uncleanness—recalling the authority given to spiritual shepherds.

verses.text: "The leper who has the disease must wear torn clothes, let the hair of his head hang loose, and cover his mouth, crying, 'Unclean, unclean.'
verses.comment: Outward signs of impurity declare separation from community. 'Cover his mouth' shows humility and acknowledgment of spiritual need.

verses.text: He shall remain unclean as long as he has the disease. He is unclean. He must live alone; his dwelling must be outside the camp.
verses.comment: Isolation prefigures Christ bearing reproach outside the camp (Hebrews 13:11-13), showing His solidarity with the outcast and suffering.

verses.text: "When there is a disease like leprosy in a garment, whether in a woolen or linen garment,
verses.comment: Uncleanness extends to garments, emphasizing total purity in body and environment.

verses.text: in warp or woof of linen or wool, or in a leather object, or anything made of leather,
verses.comment: All materials are subject to examination, showing that purity is comprehensive in the life of faith.

verses.text: if the disease is greenish or reddish in the garment, leather, warp, or woof, or anything made of leather, it is a disease like leprosy and shall be shown to the priest.
verses.comment: Garments, symbols of righteousness, show that purity extends to all aspects of a person’s life.

verses.text: The priest shall examine the disease and isolate the affected item for seven days.
verses.comment: Even physical objects undergo examination, implying that holiness touches all things.

verses.text: He shall examine the disease on the seventh day. If the disease has spread in the garment, warp, woof, or leather, whatever its use, the disease is active leprosy. The item is unclean.
verses.comment: Uncleanness in objects is handled as in persons, emphasizing that holiness and impurity are not just private matters.

verses.text: He must burn the garment, the wool or linen warp or woof, or anything made of leather where the disease is. For it is active leprosy; it shall be burned with fire.
verses.comment: Destruction by burning is a type of judgment; see Revelation 20:14—eternal consequences for uncleanness not healed.

verses.text: But if the priest examines the item and the disease has not spread in the garment, warp, woof, or leather,
verses.comment: Lack of progression means further examination is warranted; patience always precedes judgment.

verses.text: the priest shall order it to be washed and isolate it for another seven days.
verses.comment: Washing the garment is a sign of purification—symbolizing the grace of cleansing through sacramental means.

verses.text: After washing, if the disease has changed its appearance but not spread, it is still unclean. You must burn the item, whether the disease has faded or not, for the disease has penetrated.
verses.comment: If the impurity persists after attempted cleansing, it must be destroyed—prefigures final spiritual judgment.

verses.text: But if the priest examines the item and the disease has faded after washing, he shall tear the affected area out of the garment, leather, warp, or woof.
verses.comment: Removal of the damaged part preserves the whole—see Jude 1:23 on saving others by snatching them out of fire.

verses.text: But if it appears again in the garment, warp, woof, or leather article, it is an active leprosy, and the item must be burned with fire.
verses.comment: Persistent uncleanness calls for decisive action, echoing the doctrine of judgment after rejection of grace.

verses.text: If the spot has faded from the garment, warp, woof, or leather after washing, the item shall be washed a second time, and it is clean.
verses.comment: Repeated washing highlights the patience of divine mercy and thorough restoration—a pattern for spiritual healing.

verses.text: This is the law for disease like leprosy in garments of wool or linen, warp or woof, and any leather object, for pronouncing them clean or unclean.
verses.comment: The law closes with a comprehensive summary, suggesting that purity and cleanness reach every part of the believer’s life. The priestly office stands as God’s agent for healing and discernment—foreshadowing the fullness of sacramental ministry in the New Covenant.
